What‚Äôs more important than being the President of the United States of America?  For all of us here, that‚Äôs a no-brainer. But each day I find myself asking that of the president-elect.  Last night, we watched President Obama say farewell to the country he served. For the past eight years parts of our country disparaged him and some of our colleagues fought him tooth and nail at the expense of their constituents. But each day we were assured that our outgoing president put this country and our interests first.  President-elect Trump serves himself.  Yesterday, several news sources reported a possibility of continuing exchange of information between Russia and Trump campaign officials during the election.  So in the face of yet another troubling revelation that further sullies the ground on which his loyalty to America stands on - I have questions:  Is our president-elect willing to sacrifice personal gain for the good of this great nation?   When will we find out if he has fulfilled his legal responsibility to pay taxes like millions of American‚Äôs do?   How can we be sure that our interests will take precedent if we don‚Äôt know if they ever have?  Will the White House serve as Trump Tower South?  The actions and words of the President of the United States have a loud and reverberating effect through the world economy and the international political system.   To date, president-elect Trump‚Äôs promises to America have been hollow and his actions self-serving.   Donald Trump does not merely offer an alternative direction for our nation; he offers to use the Presidency primarily for his personal benefit.   When given opportunity to set these concerns aside, he scoffs at his critics and embraces our nation‚Äôs enemies.   Instead of making reasonable attempts to reassure the American public, whom he will soon swear to protect, he gaslights us with tweets, mockery, and lies.  In the past, we‚Äôve seen the term Un-American used to indict members of the public executing their civil liberties.   Anti-war advocates protesting for peace have been called un-American;  Civil rights leaders standing against discrimination have been called un-American (ask Jeff Sessions);  Professional athletes taking a knee to acknowledge sordid realities within our justice system are deemed un-American;   And comedians and pastors alike for using their microphones to criticize our nation.   But quite frankly, dissent is American.   Protest is American.   Criticism is American.   Healthy skepticism toward our national intelligence is American - disparaging and discrediting them is not.  Working with foreign powers to ensure peace is not only American, but also presidential - inviting a foreign power to compromise the cyber security of private citizens is not.  Empowering Americans to become involved in the political process, take action and even be critical of you is American ‚Äì attacking them when they call untruths and inciting your supporters to do the same is not.  Of these reasons and a host of others, I simply ask‚Äîat what point do the actions of our next president Donald Trump, meet the threshold of Un-American?

Born in the town of Liuhe in Taicang, Jiangsu province, China she earned a physics degree at National Central University in Nanjing and then migrated to the United States to attend University of California, Berkeley. She was widely known for her work on the Manhattan Project at Columbia University where she developed a process which allowed larger quantities of fuel to be produced, by increasingly enriching uranium. This amendment reflects a simple idea: Federal funds should not be used for discrimination. Currently, schools receiving voucher money are prohibited from discriminating against students based on race, color, national origin, religion, or sex.   My amendment would add sexual orientation and gender identity. This committee is clearly divided on the merits of private school vouchers. But, to those who believe vouchers are necessary to provide opportunities to students in struggling schools, surely we must require that those opportunities be available to all students.   Yet, under current law, LGBT students can be denied admission, expelled, or otherwise treated negatively just because of their sexual orientation or gender identity. For a federally funded program, that is unacceptable.  LGBT youths are particularly likely to be bullied or physically assaulted at school, making it particularly essential that we ensure this vulnerable population is protected from discrimination. This amendment would simply give them the same protections we give other students participating in the DC voucher program.  Some of my colleagues may have concerns about interfering with private institutions. But, these schools make a choice to participate in the DC voucher program. If they don‚Äôt want to abide by non-discrimination principles, they are free to not accept federal money. It is entirely reasonable to expect schools that accept taxpayer dollars, including from the LGBT taxpayers in all of our districts, to spend that money in a non-discriminatory way.  Just earlier this year, President Trump announced he will keep in place President Obama‚Äôs executive order prohibiting federal contractors from discriminating against employees on the basis of sexual orientation or gender identity.   This decision reflects a growing bipartisan consensus that those who choose to accept federal money should not use those funds to discriminate.   I urge my colleagues on both sides of the aisle join me in applying this logic to the DC voucher program by supporting this amendment.

Today we shine a light on world-renowned writer, lecturer, political activist, and feminist organizer Gloria Steinem who in the 1960s-70s pioneered a movement which would be coined as the ‚ÄúSecond-Wave of Feminism.‚Äù . At the age of 10, Steinem became her mentally ill mother‚Äôs caregiver until she left to attend Smith College. At Smith, she studied government, a non-traditional choice for a woman at that time. . After finishing her degree in 1956, Steinem received a fellowship to study in India. She wrote for Indian publications, and was influenced by Gandhian activism. She first worked for Independent Research Service and then established a career for herself as a freelance writer. . In the late 1960s, she helped create New York magazine, and wrote a column on politics for the publication. Steinem became more engaged in the women's movement after reporting on an abortion hearing given by the radical feminist group known as the Redstockings. . She expressed her feminist views in such essays as "After Black Power, Women's Liberation." . In 1971 Steinem joined other prominent feminists, such as Bella Abzug and Betty Friedan, in forming the National Women's Political Caucus, which worked on behalf of women's issues. She also took the lead in launching the pioneering, feminist Ms. magazine. It began as an insert in New York magazine but its first independent issue appeared in January 1972. . Under her direction, the magazine tackled important topics, including domestic violence. Ms. became the first national publication to feature the subject on its cover in 1976. . Steinem has received a host of accolades and awards for her activism and feminism for decades and continues to remain on the forefront of human rights and women‚Äôs issues. . She is also host and executive producer of the Emmy-nominated VICE series, WOMAN. . As the fights of yesterday mirror our challenges today, we continue to move forward the fight for equality on all fronts. . #womenshistorymonth #WHM #OurHistoryIsOurStrength

Today, we feature Kenyan environmental political activist, and 2004 Nobel Peace Prize Laureate, Wangari Muta Maathai. . Wangari Muta Maathai was born in rural Kenya in 1940. She was the first woman in East and Central Africa to earn a doctorate degree, become an associate professor in that region, or become chair of the Department of Veterinary Anatomy. . Professor Maathai earned three degrees; a Bachelors in Biological Sciences from Mount St. Scholastica College in 1964, a Master of Science degree from the University of Pittsburgh in 1966, and obtained her PhD in 1971 from the University of Nairobi. . Professor Maathai was active on the National Council of Women of Kenya, and also the chairman from 1981 to 1987. While chairman, she developed her ideas into a broad-based, grassroots organization, the Green Belt Movement (GBM). . The main focus is the planting of trees with women groups in order to conserve the environment and improve their quality of life. Through GBM, she has assisted women in planting more than 20 million trees on their farms and on schools and church compounds. . In acknowledgement of her deep commitment to the environment, Professor Maathai was awarded with a number of accolades including;  being named UN Messenger of Peace in 2009, becoming a trustee of the Karura Forest Environmental Education Trust in 2010, and in partnership with the University of Nairobi, she founded the Wangari Maathai Institute for Peace and Environmental Studies (WMI). . Professor Maathai‚Äôs commitment to protecting our environment is not only inspiring, but it reminds us that we must keep taking bold steps to protect our planet and ensure access to safe, clean, and productive environment. . #WHM #womenshistorymonth #OurHistoryIsOurStrength

She hopes that better medications will be developed in the near future that will allow her to support herself, live independently, and have the life she‚Äôs always dreamed of. Caitlin has had to face the reality that, without it, she could lose the ability to work altogether and would ultimately have no choice but to go back on opioids -- which make her sick and worsen the fatigue -- because she wouldn't be able to afford the medications approved for her condition. ‚ÄúI'm only 28 but my life would effectively be over without the ability to manage my condition,‚Äù she says.  Thousands of people like Caitlin are counting on us so that they can continue to afford the quality healthcare they deserve. Join us in the fight to protect healthcare for all Americans.
